Democracy doesn't tolerate autocrats, even in state legislatures. No one person or body should have absolute power over elections.

I wish petitioners had made this argument, although I can see strategic reasons for not doing so. But I welcome the message SCOTUS telegraphed to wacko state supreme courts like NC voters just threw out last November./7
because "[t]he legislative defendants did not meaningfully present the issue in their petition for certiorari or in their briefing, nor did they press the matter at oral argument."/6

"We hold only that state courts may not transgress the ordinary bounds of  judicial review such that they arrogate to themselves the power vested in state legislatures to regulate federal elections." The Court "decline[d] to address whether the [NC] Supreme Court" did that .../5

any more than a federal district court can by reading content into the US Constitution that isn't there. Doing that is what Rucho v. Common Cause (2019) recognized was a LEGISLATIVE rather than JUDICIAL act. It remains so when done by a state supreme court, as the Court held:/4

The good news is that EVERY JUSTICE acknowledges that those limits must indeed be policed. Thus, a rabidly partisan state supreme court like NC's that decided Harper below cannot make up constraints on the legislature that the state constitution does not actually state, .../3

But I never saw the need to argue the full "independent legislature theory," although I do get Justice Thomas's point that rejecting it leaves the federal judiciary with the task to police the limits of state court adjudication of state constitutions in Elections Clause cases./2

This ruling is a big win for democracy and you as a voter.

However, the existing protections against gerrymandering remain far too weak - in red and blue states.

We should be strengthening them to guard us from politicians who use redistricting to minimize your voice.

If SCOTUS had ruled in favor of the theory, it would have started a gerrymandering arms race between red and blue states.

It also would have likely resulted in the handful of existing independent redistricting commissions being struck down.

The Supreme Court just rightfully - and forcefully - struck down the independent state legislature theory in Moore v. Harper.

The theory held that the Constitution gives state legislatures *sole and complete power* to draw districts however they want, without judicial oversight.
